attributes.address: Alameda Porto de Santos, 214 - Ilha Comprida - São Paulo, 11925-000, Brazil
attributes.title: Export

attributes.description:
The world's largest hydrofluoric acid plant. Hydrofluoric acid is a dangerous chemical to work with. In January, one worker died and others were injured at a Samsung factory. 

The US produces some hydrofluoric acid, importing the fluorspar from China and Mexico. Fluorspar is among the products in the tantalum chain that the US both imports and exports, or reexports, as the export of an imported product is termed (US Geological Survey, 2012).

Sulfur and fluorspar combine to make hydrofluoric acid. Each ton of end-product uses roughly 2.59 tons of sulfuric acid, 2.7 tons of fluorspar and 1.6 tons of water, and produces 1.8 tons of gas waste and 4 tons of solid waste. iPhone production is but one tiny part of this, but electronics in general and green technologies are becoming larger sources of hydrofluoric acid.
attributes.title: Hydrofluoric acid

attributes.description: Baotou is an industrial city in Inner Mongolia and one of the leading sources of rare earth minerals of all kinds. Tantalum from all over the world ends up in this smelting facility. Baotou is notorious for high levels of pollution and is at the center of some of the paradoxes in global climate change discussions. China is scolded internationally for its polluting; it is equally unpopular when it attempts to limit rare earth (and other) production or account for environmental costs and impose regulations, as this increases costs. Like the tantalum, the destinations of many rare earth minerals produced in Baotou are for clean technologies (Buckley, 2010).
attributes.title: Smelting

attributes.description:
The DR Congo is likely the largest source of tantalum today (US Geological Survey, 2012 & Cramer, 2012). Most of it comes from labour intensive artisanal mining, which poses health risks to the miners, including exposure to radiation, and has been one among many fuels of conflict there for many years. In 2000, when global demand for tantalum peaked during the high-tech boom, various regional groups turned to coltan to finance their efforts. During the boom, corporations and the US government stockpiled tantalum fearing future shortage. Supply outpaced demand in the following years and prices plummeted, and in 2008, with prices low and global consumption suffering, mines in Australia and Canada, and an increase in material came from DR Congo. 
Reports often imply that the war, and the five million dead, is caused by mineral competition, specifically coltan. This story is well publicized and has many antecedents, such as blood diamonds. Guided by this notion, NGOs, industry...cont'd
attributes.title: Coltan mining

attributes.description: Smelting is a water-intensive process, both while producing tantalum and discharging the waste. Thus, like many such facilities, this one is located near a large river, The Pearl River Delta. Among other environmental affects, ammonia and ammonium salts are released via the post-production industrial wastewater (Sing, 2007). A high asthma rate in Conghua is among the health concerns associated with its industrial parks.
attributes.title: Smelting facility

attributes.description: Vishay Intertechnology is an important iPhone supplier. To understand the complex production of a capacitor, watch the youtube video. Although produced for Kemet, not an Apple supplier, the process is similar.
attributes.title: Capacitor manufacturing

attributes.description:
Foxconn operates the world's largest iPhone plant.  Most of the 120,000 workers are migrant workers and they work an average 238 hrs/month @ $1.65/hour*. At that rate, an employee would have to work 24 hours/day 365 days/year for 26,151 years to earn Apple's CEO Tim Cook's 2011 payment package. Hard work can pay off! A portion of their wage is deducted for food, dorms, and laundry services. Although this plant has gained notoriety from events like the 2011 explosion that killed 4 employees and injured many others, and the spate of suicides that prompted the installation of suicide nets to catch potential jumpers, conditions at this factory are reported to be favourable compared to some other of Apple's Chinese suppliers, such as the Riteng, where iPhone cases are made, and workers average 346 hours/month. 

*Due to nondisclosure by Apple and its subsidiaries, these numbers are based on a worker survey.
attributes.title: iPhone Manufacturer
Tantalum mining
attributes.description:
After the global recession in 2008, Brazil increased tantalum production. AMG's mixed mineral open pit mine is the country's most productive tantalum mine. The ore was formed during the Cretaceous period, over 100 MYA, and is estimated to have 30 years of reserves. Brazil’s primary export market in 2011 was China but it also exports tantalum concentrate and ores to the US, which the US reexports to Brazil (US geological survey, 2012).
The most common ores containing tantalum are columbium and tantalite. Earth to tantalum is a vigorous and toxic process. First, large amounts of earth are uncovered, and the ore is extracted from the earth by digging and blasting. The ore is crushed by hand or machine and then digested with hydrofluoric acid and sulfuric acid. This happens at or near the site to increase concentration of shipped material. Radioactive chemicals uranium and thorium are released. Tailing ponds store waste material. 
Photos: Mibra mine; conveyor belt collecting tantalite ore.

attributes.title: Tantalum mine
attributes.description:
The Paranapanema Group's Pitinga mine is another important tantalum source in Brazil. Several thousand hectares of Amazon forest were cleared, and dams and ponds and waste have affected the region’s rivers. 
The Waimiri-Atroari are the area's indigenous residents. Anthropologist Stephen Baines of the University of Brasilia has spent much time with them. He outlines how they’ve been used in government and industry propaganda, while legislation continues to favour mining company's and threaten the existence of this people. His observations have many similarities the indigenous struggles against mining and other industries throughout the Amazon, in the DR Congo, and throughout the world. The story posed by the government and industry about indigenous corporation is much different from what the indigenous people themselves are saying (Baines, 1999).

attributes.title: Fluorspar
attributes.description:
Acid-grade fluorspar, or acidspar, is used to make hydrofluoric acid. Though rich in reserves, high labour costs and dangerous mining conditions make profitability of mining fluorspar difficult in Canada and the US. Both are attempting to reinvigorate the production of this vital resource, partly in response to threats of China limiting its exports. Canada's largest deposit is in Newfoundland. An American businessman owned and operated a mine at St. Lawrence for several decades in the mid-20th century. On its website, Heritage Newfoundland talks about the deaths, and physical and social costs associated with fluorspar mining and today the town is a skeleton of its former self. The reality of abandoned mines, and correlated social problems, is perhaps the most invisible of the inevitable remnants of any supply chain dependent upon finite mined minerals.

Cheaper labour and looser regulations allow China and Mexico to produce fluorspar for an market-appropriate price.

attributes.title: Sulfur
attributes.description:
The valued physical characteristics of tantalum make extracting and producing it intense and complicated. Hydrofluoric and sulfuric acid are directly needed (beyond all the externalities like energy, machine production, etc.). The journey, then, of tantalum often begins, like most things, with oil, and the sulfur produced from it. North America produces about 1/4 of global elemental sulfur, and exports to China, where much of it ends up as hydrofluoric acid. Canada’s carbon footprint benefits from this exchange and Canadian consumers receive the final commodities, including iPhones. 

Photo: world’s largest sulfur plant in the Gulf of Mexico. Source: Freeport-McMoRan Sulphur Inc. August 17, 2000.

attributes.title: Fluorspar
attributes.address: Xiangzhen Road, Xingqing, Yinchuan, Ningxia, China
attributes.description: Cheaper labour and looser regulations allow China and Mexico to produce fluorspar for a market-appropriate price.

attributes.title: Hydrofluoric acid
attributes.description:
Mexichem operates Mexico's largest hydrofluoric acid facilities. 


The US produces some hydrofluoric acid, importing the fluorspar from China and Mexico. Fluorspar is among the products in the tantalum chain that the US both imports and exports, or reexports, as the export of an imported product is termed (US Geological Survey, 2012).

Sulfur and fluorspar combine to make hydrofluoric acid. Each ton of end-product uses roughly 2.59 tons of sulfuric acid, 2.7 tons of fluorspar and 1.6 tons of water, and produces 1.8 tons of gas waste and 4 tons of solid waste. iPhone production is but one tiny part of this, but electronics in general and green technologies are becoming larger sources of hydrofluoric acid.

attributes.title: Hydrofluoric acid
attributes.description: Elemental sulfur and fluorspar are used to make hydrofluoric acid. Each ton of end-product uses roughly 2.59 tons of sulfuric acid, 2.7 tons of fluorspar and 1.6 tons of water, and produces 1.8 tons of gas waste and 4 tons of solid waste.

attributes.title: Tantalum mines
attributes.description: Australia was the world's leading producer of tantalum for some decades before 2008. In 2009, production slowed. The lower price of tantalum, high wages in Australia, and cheaper availability elsewhere were all contributing factors. Its largest mine, Wodgina, stopped operations. Wodgina's deposits were formed in the Archaean age, nearly 3 billion years ago. It is among the world's richest tantalum deposits, with enough to sustain 2008 production rates for 25 years.

attributes.title: Disposal
attributes.description:
Tantalum is one of many toxic components in an iPhone that pose environmental concerns. Once in a landfill, it breaks down and enters the ecosystem as toxic waste, contaminating the waters and posing a health problem to the nearby residents.
Apple boasts about its recycling campaign, claiming to have increased recycled weight by 70%. They arrive at this number by comparing last year's recycling with the amount of products sold 7 years ago, when sales were less than a quarter what they are today. So if they sell 12 phones and recycle three, they recycle 100% of their products!
  

But there are more complicated post-consumption realities than Apple’s spurious accounting practices. The smallness of phones and their components make reusing anything very difficult. It is an extremely labour-intensive process requiring many hands, a pay-rate far below what's available in the US or Canada, and exposure to toxic chemicals. Recycled phones often end up in China, India, or Africa.

attributes.title: Recycled phones
attributes.description: Phones imported from developed countries are prominent at the recycling center in Ghana’s capital where they are manually dismantled. Toxins are released and the site’s pollutants enters the Korle Lagoon (Otsuka et al, 2011)..

attributes.title: Recycled phones
attributes.description: 60 minutes traced electronics recycled in Denver to Guiyu.

North America was the largest market for the 125 million iPhones sold in 2012. As part of its environmental commitment, Apple (2013) reduced its package size by 42%. It boasts about the reduced space required to ship phones. Shipping the finished iPhone, as we’ve seen, represents only a tiny fraction of total shipping. More revealing though is that increased sales, which result largely from planned obsolescence and aggressive marketing by Apple, means that in 2012, 66 times more shipments were required to get the iPhone to its consumers compared with 2007, the year to which their improved environmental practices are compared.
attributes.title: iPhone Manufacturer to Consumers

attributes.description:
China is both the world’s largest producer and importer of elemental sulfur.

Photo: some sulfur exported from Vancouver to China returns as consumer commodities. Source: vancoolver.com
